data.title: contentText for before & after decorations does not always appear
Issue with font color when using terminal and ssh connection
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: Windows 7

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  Turn on black theme
2. Start integrated temrinal
3. Log in via ssh to some Linux machine (e.g. CentOS)
4. Type ll (ls -l)

Folder names will be unreadable due to green font color and green font background.

By the way, support for public/private key authentication and storing sites would be just great!

Keep going, this editor is really becoming amazing!!
![issue](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11991790/16268722/bb77e5dc-388f-11e6-9913-57472e230857.PNG)
!

data.title: Type script syntax highlighting error
Support cygwin git

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Build 14367

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Install Cygwin
2. Edit .vscode/settings.json to set `git.path` to point to `"\\cygwin64\\bin\\git.exe`
3. VS Code throws up an error message of `ENOENT: no such file or directory, lstat 'C:\cygdrive'`, as described [here](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/36508177/visual-studio-code-cannot-detect-cygwin-git-exe-path)

This is, of course, because Cygwin namespaces the filesystem differently. However, doing this (which usually fixes things in other tools):

```
        "git.path": "\\cygwin64\\bin\\bash.exe git",
```

...then results in further confusion as Code apparently does not have a way to correctly set the environment for the git process, which then defaults to the wrong PATH:

```
git fetch
git show HEAD:.vscode/settings.json
git show HEAD:.vscode/settings.json
Could not create directory '/c/cygwin64/home/USERNAME/.ssh'.
ssh_askpass: exec(/usr/local/bin/win-ssh-askpass.exe): No such file or directory
Host key verification failed.
fatal: Could not read from remote repository.

Please make sure you have the correct access rights
and the repository exists.
git fetch
Could not create directory '/c/cygwin64/home/USERNAME/.ssh'.
ssh_askpass: exec(/usr/local/bin/win-ssh-askpass.exe): No such file or directory
Host key verification failed.
fatal: Could not read from remote repository.

Please make sure you have the correct access rights
and the repository exists.
```

Trying to set PATH, HOME, etc. inline in the `bash` command line above fails for some reason I cannot yet fathom, but I would suggest a configuration setting `git.env` be created so that the environment external Git tools can be pre-configured (this would also benefit the Linux and OSX ports).

As to why this is necessary and why I can't use other Git binaries on Windows, the reason is simple: 

Cygwin does Git over SSH "right", with completely identical setup in terms of SSH keys, options, CR/LF encoding, etc. Current Git for Windows simply does not work for my use case (I've tried), and, obviously, the Linux Subsystem doesn't help with this either.

data.title: The error and warning list increments with the same items after every typing.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12 Beta(16A201w)

Steps to Reproduce:

I was using VS Code with **Legacy OmniSharp** to develop Unity projects. There is a plugin I used has a wrapper script used a namespace that Unity somehow did not expose (although the code compiles since the namespace does exist), which shows as an error. There are also several warnings due to unnecessary using directives.Whenever I stop typing the error/warning counter would go up and it would be several duplicated entries for one error/warning. 
1. Open a Unity project and set up to use VS Code with [dotBunny/VSCode](https://github.com/dotBunny/VSCode).
2. Create a new script and write something so that it makes an error or a warning.
3. Create another script, and while writing things in it, watch the error/warning counters go up whenever OmniSharp does the check. Reveling the list will show duplicated error/waring items.

data.title: Show 'no installed extensions' affordance
Git integration fails to see merged file as staged if I reject all incoming edits

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
VS Code Version 1.2.1
Commit fe7f407b95b7f78405846188259504b34ef72761
Date 2016-06-14T13:00:22.146Z
Shell 0.37.6
Renderer 49.0.2623.75
Node 5.10.0
Windows 10 Enterprise x64, latest non-Insider
git version 2.9.0.windows.1

Description: during a Git merge process, VSCode can sometimes show no pending changes and refuse to let me commit, while command-line Git believes a merge is in progress and lets me commit. This occurs if the changed file contains no changes (after merge) that came from the commit that I am merging into my local state.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create Git repository (e.g. on GitHub).
2. Clone to working folder A.
3. In working folder A, commit a file with some arbitrary text. Commit and sync
4. Clone to working folder B.
5. In working folder B, change some part of the file. Commit and sync.
6. In working folder A, change some part of the file, conflicting with previous. Commit and sync.

This will result in a merge conflict due to the change from working folder B getting pulled.

Resolve the conflict by removing all changes pulled form working folder B - the file should be the same as the committed state that existed in working folder A. Stage the file to mark the file as resolved.

Expected result: file is staged and VSCode lets you commit the merge.

Actual result: file disappears from Git tab and VSCode says cannot commit as there are no pending changes.

`git commit` from the command line works fine to finish the merge, only VSCode refuses to cooperate here.

data.title: Installing the extension via command line does not update extension viewlet

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
1. Have an extension installed
2. Open the extension viewlet
3. Uninstall that extension from the command line
4. Go back to vscode - the extension still apears as installed and you can click uninstall
5. The extension now gets installed - even though I clicked uninstall

Perfectly the viewlet would update as soon as you use the command line. If that is not possible I would at least not expect that clicking on uninstall installs the extension again

data.title: Uninstalling an extension only removes latest version of that extension
data.body:
Not sure if this is expected.
1. Manually change the version of an extension you have installed
2. Start vscode - get offered an update to that extension -> update it
3. Now uninstall that extension
4. Restart vscode -> notice the extension is still in the list and an update is offered

The issue is that the uninstall only removed the latest version of my extension. I would expect that all versions of my extension get removed.

data.title: Update extension button doesn't disable when clicked
data.body:
1. Open extensions viewlet - some extensions need update
2. Click the update button - there is no indication that an update is taking place
3. I can click on the update button infinite number of times. I would expect the update button gets disabled after first click

data.title: Hover obscures previous code

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce: 
1. write function name followed by open paren `(` character

When typing in the parameters to a function, I want to see the code I just wrote, but the automatic Parameter Hinting pop-up box often covers up the previous lines, sometimes hiding up to the previous 4 lines of code! This can be especially annoying when the parameters I am typing span multiple lines.
To fix this problem I have been adding the following custom CSS style to the VSCode Developer Tools:
`.editor-widget:hover { opacity: .15; }` 
However, it would be nice if there was a way that I could disable the Parameter Hinting so I don't have to press `ESC` each time I am typing parameters and want to get rid of the hinting box. A different fix to this problem would be if the parameter hinting was out of the way, by being below the current line of code for example.

data.title: [question]: Can HTML previews fetch/XHR content from virtual document URIs?
data.body:
I was very delighted to find out that HTML previews could run JavaScript, which is the whole reason my vscode-map-preview extension (https://github.com/jumpinjackie/vscode-map-preview) exists.

One of the questions I have, is that the HTML preview I generate with the extension is not so much content, but a combination of an interactive viewer "container" into the actual content that is also embedded into the same preview HTML.

One of the small annoyances is that I have to sanitize the document content for any unruly characters before embedding into the preview HTML so that the content doesn't break out of the ES6 template string that I have defined in the preview HTML script block for this content.

What would be nicer and cleaner for me is if instead of embedding the document content into the preview HTML, is if I could define a 2 virtual documents (with their own URI schemes):
1. For the viewer "container" HTML 
2. For the actual document content

Then HTML preview I generate from the 1st virtual document can fetch/XHR the content from, allowing for the graceful ability to handle failures in setting up the preview. Currently any failures in previewing content are mostly silent, and I would have to physically dump the preview HTML content out to a separate file in my extension code and open that up in Chrome to see what's wrong with it. 

Is this possible to make fetch/XHR inside a HTML preview work with virtual documents in vscode?

data.title: Key binding error or docs... or operator...?
data.body:
I'm getting the below message when using the key binding you can see in the same screenshot.

I took the 'command' from the docs at https://code.visualstudio.com/Docs/customization/keybindings

In this Insiders build, 'ctrl+shift+m`is mapped to`workbench.actions.view.problems`, and that does work, but is different action to the above. Has the above feature been withdrawn and replaced?
